page.title: 07RIBBLE ESTUARY/SALT MARSHES
page.content: {Spartina townsendii}(Spartina grass) originated from South America.It moved north from Southampton to Lytham,it now covers a vast area of Lytham shoreline.It grows to about 18ins. high.The long leaves are striped gold and yellow and develop into tufts.It is now an eyesore.In an attempt to control it some of the grass has been sprayed -without success.The silt deposited by the Ribble has formed mud flats in the estuary.These are colonised by the Spartina which encourages further mud to settle, raising the level of the salt marsh. A commercial dock was constucted by Squire Clifton in 1840 but in 1885 it virtually ceased to function.The Ribble Cruising Club now occupy those docks where vessels are moored.The Ribble Estuary once led to the port of Preston which closed in 1981.
